tax:treatment.tax:nomenclature:
†
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Zirngiebl, 1937 Allantus nigrolinearis (Zirngiebl, 1937) new status

tax:ref_group.tax:p:
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Emphytus balteatus nigrolinearis variety Emphytus balteatus var. nigrolinearis Zirngiebl, 1937: 646; ♀, holotype [not examined]. Type locality: Kristallenia (Kreta) [= Panagia Kristalenia, Lasithi Plateau, East Crete].Blank 1996; synonym of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus balteatus species Allantus balteatus (Klug, 1818).Lacourt 1999; synonym of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Emphytus laticinctus species Emphytus laticinctus (Serville, 1823).
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus nigrolinearis variety Allantus didymus var. nigrolinearis (Zirngiebl, 1937);Schedl 1981; misidentification.

tax:div.tax:p:
The barcodes of two sequenced
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis specimens (DEIGISHym20641, 20642) are identical and amongst 34 sequenced specimens of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus sensu lato, are most similar to those of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne Liston and Jacobs, 2012 from Cyprus (DEIGISHym11089, 11093), with divergence of about 3.9%. Minimal divergence of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis from
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus (France BC ZSM 01149 and Italy, Sicily DEIGISHym11042) is 6.4%. Noteworthy is that divergence of 5.3% between
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus (Klug, 1818) (Italy DEIGISHym18775, and Germany; 10 specimens) is somewhat less than from
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus. Several other segregates cluster around the four named taxa in the barcode similarity tree, indicating that the species group requires revision and may contain more taxa than previously thought.

As noted byBlank (1996), Zirngiebl apparently had no clear concept of species, subspecies and varieties. His
Animalia Insecta Lepidoptera Lasiocampidae Symphyta nigrolinearis variety var. nigrolinearis was described within a paragraph discussing colour variability of a reared series of female
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Emphytus balteatus species Emphytus balteatus from Germany. However, his wording does not make it clear what relationship he considered his new variety to have to the other specimens. In the absence of any clear indication that Zirngiebl considered
Animalia Insecta Lepidoptera Lasiocampidae Symphyta nigrolinearis species nigrolinearis to be of infrasubspecific rank, the name is available (ICZN 1999, Article 45.6.4.).

Female
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis differ from those of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne in having an uninterrupted, broad, median, black vitta through the otherwise red sterna of the abdomen (Fig. 2). In the other species a number of sterna are entirely red. The metatibia of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis females is also darker: apical half, and base narrowly, fuscous. In the other species the metatibia is entirely red except for apex. In two
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis the otherwise red abdominal terga 3-6 have a median black stripe (Fig. 3). In the third female, this stripe is interrupted on tergum 5 and the metatibia is somewhat paler than in the other specimens. The four basal serrulae of the lancet of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis (Fig. 1) are subtriangular and similar to the other serrulae, whereas the four basal serrulae of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne are more rounded than the others (Liston and Jacobs 2012, Figs 4, 6). The males of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne are indistinguishable, apparently including their penis valves (
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis: Fig. 4.
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne:Liston and Jacobs 2012, Fig. 7), but differ in leg colour from
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus. In
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis and
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus ariadne species Allantus ariadne the mid femur is almost entirely black except for the apex, but in
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus approximately the apical half of the mid femur is pale. The holotype of
Animalia Insecta Lepidoptera Lasiocampidae Symphyta nigrolinearis variety var. nigrolinearis was mistakenly considered bySchedl (1981,1993) to belong to
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus (Klug, 1818) (Schedl 2011).Schedl (2011) added a record from Crete of a male specimen which he determined as
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus. However, confusion of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus with
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus (sensu lato) has been widespread, particularly of the males (Koch 1988). Until more convincing evidence for the occurrence of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus didymus species Allantus didymus in Crete is presented, the name should be removed from the faunal list of the island.

tax:figure.tax:p:
Figures 1-4.
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis, Crete. 1, lancet, ♀, scale = 0.2 mm. 2, underside of abdomen, ♀, scale = 1 mm. 3, upperside of abdomen, ♀, scale = 1 mm. 4, penis valve, ♂, scale = 0.2 mm.

tax:div.tax:p:
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus laticinctus species Allantus laticinctus has only definitely been reared from
Plantae Magnoliopsida Rosales Rosaceae Rosa genus Rosa, in central and western Europe (Taeger et al. 1998,Knight 2006). The host(s) of
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Allantus nigrolinearis species Allantus nigrolinearis are likely to be
Animalia Insecta Lepidoptera Rosaceae Symphyta family Rosaceae (because the known hosts of other species in this complex are
Animalia Insecta Lepidoptera Rosaceae Symphyta family Rosaceae), but as for
Animalia Insecta Hymenoptera Tenthredinidae Empria archangelskii species Empria archangelskii (see below), several host species seem possible.
